This is a spread from my short comic "I Will Fly," created as a part of the Illustration Academy summer comics summer workshop. The prompt was to create a five-page story using with all poses and backgrounds referenced from only black and white photos. Watercolor and ink on illustration board; text is a custom-made font input with photoshop.

This is a cover resdesign for the book Tuck Everlasting by Natalie Babbit. The visuals on the cover reflects the importance of time and the setting of the woods to the narrative. Procreate and photoshop, with hand-lettering..

This is a spread from the novel When You Reach Me, by Rebecca Stead, which I redesigned and illustrated for my portfolio. The illustrations were done in watercolor and ink, with adjustments made in photoshop. The graphic design was done in adobe indesign.
Graphite. This work is one of several focusing on the male human figure.
Graphite. This is another piece I did on the male human form.
Acrylic. This piece was inspired by a car show in Logan, UT.

I created this painting when I first learned about the Psyche mission and Psyche Inspired back in April. The mosaic with the mission’s colors is to demonstrate the many pieces that will soon come together. The space craft is in the center and is made with aluminum foil to demonstrate how the heart of the mission is focused on mental.

This piece was inspired by the orientation for my IRIS internship last summer. I loved the bond that formed between my cohort over our love of geophysics and space. I wanted to capture the peace that we all felt on our last night while surrounded by the things we love even though we were all scared about what would happen during our internships.

This was inspired partially by the things that my mom said to me as a kid to help me, and by the bedtime routine of a 5-year-old that I babysit. Today’s world can be scary for kids, but space is consistent to them and consistency is something that can help kids remain calm and moving forward.

Time; Colored Pencil on Mylar Paper; 18”x22” Extensive reference to time. Loch Ness monster as age old mystery, lotus flower reference Greek lotus-eaters and inability to keep track of time, whales as the largest animal to ever exist within tadpole eggs as a play on life and death/immortality. Placement of small human to juxtapose ego with time.

Unnamed; Oil on canvas; 24”x36” Live, still study of the human body. Meant to promote openness, beauty, and acceptance of the nude figure. Drawn with no formal measurements. Proportions were left to basic understanding and related to other forms of the body.

Catch; Oil on primed wood canvas; 24”x24” Intended to provoke thought. Use of the jocose Nerf font on a controversial topic is meant to demonstrate mass desensitization regarding anthropogenic pollution of the mind.

“Cutting All Ties To You” is a sculptural piece with meaning. 2 anatomical hearts, paper scissors, and fragile clay hand try to cut the last tie to separate but don’t have the strength. The string enters one valve where blood pumps out and enters the other valve where old blood enters, representing the relationship. Efforts to separate are futile.

“Chrysanthemums” is a piece showcasing detail in the flowers and how there are details our eyes may not see. For example, some colors depicted are not how they appear but instead what our emotions see that enhance an image/subject.
“Mafic” is an oil pastel abstract piece focusing on color theory rather than subject. I wanted viewers to look more about the colors and shapes around them instead of just the objects themselves.
This piece was inspired by the film The Life Aquatic and pictures one of the main characters, as well as smaller aquatic elements from the film.
This is a sample of my specialty, portraits in the style of impressionism.
This is a sample of a geometric direction I also often play with.

After the storm, the umbrellas washed up to the streets. The girl curiously reaches to read the posters, unknowingly learning about the future pressures she must endure. 剩女is a derogatory term that describes unmarried women over 25. In marriage markets, parents fill out their children’s profiles without their consents to advertise them to marry.

Afraid of the light, she keeps her umbrella tight against her body wherever she goes. For if the light even touches her, she will instantly become dirty. Colorism is deeply embedded in Asia’s culture, and women go to extreme lengths even bringing an umbrella everywhere to keep themselves white as dark skin is seen as filthy, undesirable, and old.

In a single splash, their face, identity, confidence; everything is robbed. What may seem like water is undoubtedly acid, as it instantly dissolves their 7 layers of skin and bones. About 1000 acid attacks are reported yearly in India. Perpetrators are usually jealous men who’ve been rejected by women seeking to disfigure, torture, or kill them.
3 side by side 11"x14" acrylic paintings done using selective lighting and local color
18"x20" black and white micron pen pointillism of octopus
16"x24" watercolor painting of a pug

I wrote this poem about my favorite beach town, Capitola. It has a small area with colored houses, and I was inspired because I wondered what it would be like if the houses were people. I wrote it whilst sitting right in front of those houses and people watching.

This is a song I wrote called Summer Blues, and was inspired by the people whom I missed as summer was coming to a close. I am a part of the multimedia team for the Daily Californian, and they asked if I could perform a song for the segment called Berkeley Beats.

This is a song I wrote called Saturday Sadness. It’s about being okay with not doing anything on a Saturday. I performed it in my hometown at an open mic at my favorite coffee shop where I study my physics. I attached the lyrics in the description of the video.

I made this piece using weaving coil, yarn, habutai silk, and silk paint, embellishing it with beads and ribbons. For this project, I drew inspiration from the portrayal of strong women in mainstream movies, specifically Wonder Woman and Mad Max: Fury Road. The chest piece represents their warrior personas while the flowing skirt their femininity.

I used felt, habutai silk, and beads for this work. My inspiration for this project came from an Indian tradition of women embellishing themselves with jasmine and hibiscus flowers to symbolically bring good luck and strength to their home. I incorporated felted jasmine buds and a fantasy hibiscus into this dress.

This work is a silk painted scarf. I was inspired by the Japanese setting and their meaning of the dragon, which is a wise and good creature made to look fierce due its power. I contrasted its fierce features with cherry blossoms to emphasize its gentleness.
This is when I heard about this program! I was so Psyched and inspired I illustrated the Psyche astroid and spacecraft!
I would love to play didgeridoo space sounds with some art pieces!
This is a collaboration video I did with some of my friends for my kids book promotions
A frame from a short animation about an astronaut figure exploring a seemingly extraterrestrial green house structure
One on my first ventures into 3D animation, frame from a quick landscape modeling practice
An animation doen in rotoscope about a dancer who struggles with her craft
This was my first project in which I tried to teach myself as many forms of digital design as possible, combining Illustrator, 3-D modeling, Photoshop, and hand drawing.
Terrell County is a short animation with an original score, drawn in a low-fidelity pixel style. The narration is taken from No Country for Old Men.

I spent a summer in Mexico City, moving there with no Spanish skills or idea of what I was going to do. St. Clair is a piece that captures the sense of open freedom and the unknown that I felt at the start of my journey.

I used acrylic paint to portray places I love and areas I wish to go. The left illustrates the fireflies in my backyard, the right illustrates the many times I go stargazing, and the middle illustrates where I would like to travel in the future to Salar de Uyuni.

I used graphite and ebony pencil to draw a portrait of my grandpa. I chose my grandpa because he has always been my father figure in my life. I wanted to illustrate his greatest quality: his patience. That is why I portrayed him to look amicable and loving, which is how I see him.

Using pen and ink I sought to pay homage to my friend who was murdered by his father on Chinese New Year 2017. This massive piece has over 550 birds flocking the trees watching over my friend. I modeled this piece after a drawing he drew when we where children.
